moves.1. d4: At the moment I prefer to play against d4 then e4 because I am in the proccess of 'booking up' on the petroff defense.
moves.1... Nf6 2. c4 c5 3. d5 e6: My two big choices here are either 3... b5 or e6 (as I did play), b5 being the benko and e6 being the benoni. I personally opt for the benoni because I feel I have more opening knowledge on the benoni but the benko I still perfectly reasonable.
moves.6. e4 Be7: 6... g6 followed by Bg7 is the norm here but I decide to play Be7 which I would say is probably worse because this bishop now has no future whilst on g7 it controls a large part of the centre.
moves.7. Bd3: Most people play Nf3 here but Bd3 is still good.
moves.8... Ne5: This is an interesting move. At first this is very weakening because after 9.Nxe5 dxe5 white will have a nice outpost on d5 which good come into good use later but it turns out that this pawn may of cost him the match.
moves.9. Nxe5 dxe5 10. O-O Bd6 11. Bg5: Here 11.Bb5+ would have been slightly better but is nothing that spectacular.
moves.12. f4: Looks good at first with the intention of the eventual pawn push to e5! but really just gives black a chance to push the strong bishop on g5 away.
moves.13. fxe5 Bxe5: White has know gone from a great postition equal to a pawn up to equal.
moves.14. Bf4 Bxf4: Bd4+ would have kept the tempo up.
moves.15. Rxf4 a6: This is a complete inaccuracy, White has a much more favourable position after 16. e5 Nd7 17. Qe2.
moves.16. a4: Black was let off the hook as it happens.
moves.16... Qd6 17. Qf3: Here I spend 45 minutes contemplating this move, can you see why? I was looking at a couple of variations including 17...Nh5 or B/Ng4. If Nh5 then white can just proceed with e5 or Rh4 (both of these are acceptable). I thought that the must surely be some way of me trapping his rook but even the computer says not.
moves.17... Bg4: Giving my undeveloped bishop a lovely outpost on the g5 square.
moves.18. Rxg4: He falls into my trap, Qe3 would of probably been a better choice.
moves.18... Nxg4 19. Qxg4 c4: This forces a loss of a piece. If 20.Bxc4 then Qc5+ wins it and if Be2 then Qb6 wins the b2 pawn which forks the knight and rook.
moves.20. Bxc4: He realises his mistake and figures this must be the way of losing it with most compensation.
moves.20... Qc5+: Qxb6 is just as good but I don't want to waste any more time if I don't need to.
An ambitious move which looks good OTB but if he had time to think about it e5 would of been more then enough compensation for the exchange.
moves.25. a5 f6: Swapping off would be beneficial for me.
moves.26. Ne2 Qe5 27. Rf1 Rac8: I don't want to take a risk with such little time so just go with what looks standard.
moves.28. Qxe5: Nf4 would have been a better choice here.
moves.28... fxe5 29. Rxf8+ Kxf8: Now he may aswell just resign, the rook can easily swipe up all of the pawns whilst the knight is virtually powerless.
moves.30. Nc3: This makes matters worse for himself.
moves.30... b4 31. Ne2 Rc2 32. Ng1 Rxb2 33. g3: This game shows how in time trouble all it takes is one mistake, the slightest inaccuracy may determine whether you have a won or lost endgame!
